large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (habitat, savannah).
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is one animal that lives in a savannah?
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to tell number stories about lions and giraffes that live on the savannah.
Help children notice how items may be different but can still add up to the same number.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What homes are in that book? What would it be like to live there?
Can you pretend to be an animal? How does that animal act?
How many animals are in that group? How did you know?
Can you write about an animal? Where do you think that animal lives?
What shapes do you see? What type of home can you make with those shapes?
What letter did you make? How did you make it?
What type of home can you build? How many blocks will you use?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science: Life Science; Earth and Space Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder resist impulses and introduce vocabulary (behavior).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to One Day on Our Blue Planet...in the Savannah.
Read closely to find moments in the book where children can discuss resisting impulses.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet; Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children count cubes with one-to-one correspondence.
Guide children to resist impulses and follow instructions while playing Simon Says.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think the home in that book looks like?
Why did you decide to act like that animal? Can you show me its behavior?
Are these two groups the same? Show me how you know.
Why did you draw [amount of animals] in this home?
Why did you change the color you were using?
Can you make an animal that starts with the letter l?
Why did you use those materials to build that animal home?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. One Day on Our Blue Planet… In the Savannah by Ella Bailey. Copyright © 2015 by Ella Bailey. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share a spatial strategy and introduce vocabulary (above, under).
Begin Story Time by revisiting One Day On Our Blue Planet...In the Savannah and asking the guiding question, What do lions do in the savannah?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review location words.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use position words, such as over, under, above, on, beside, next to, between, in front of, near, and far, top, bottom, up, down, and behind.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describes the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Ask and Answer Questions

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to explain where Pattern Blocks are in a picture using location words.
Help children ask and answer questions about the location of Pattern Blocks they have placed.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you act like one of the animals in that book?
How could you act to pretend to be a bird?
These two groups have different numbers of items. How can you make them the same?
Can you write about an animal that lives under the ground?
Can you draw a number story about five birds?
Can you write the letter x? How could you write the letter w above it?
Why did you choose those materials?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. One Day on Our Blue Planet… In the Savannah by Ella Bailey. Copyright © 2015 by Ella Bailey. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Flying Eye Books, an imprint of Nobrow Ltd.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: One Day On Our Blue Planet ...In the Savannah
Big Chart of Big Ideas: At the Pond

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to reflect on learning and introduce vocabulary (worms, grasshoppers).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts One Day On Our Blue Planet … In the Savannah and At the Pond.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s essential question: What is it like where animals live?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Use position words, such as over, under, above, on, beside, next to, between, in front of, near, and far, top, bottom, up, down, and behind.
Resist impulses (self-regulation).
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to sort animal homes by whether they are above ground, below ground, or underwater.
Help children discover similarities and differences between animal homes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think about that book?
What kind of home do you think that animal would live in? Can you pretend to be in that home?
How can we compare this group to that group? Which group is larger?
What did you write first, and why?
Why do you think this color is best to use here?
What sound does pond start with? Can you draw that letter? Can you draw a smaller one under it?
Can you make three animal homes? Can you put them in order from biggest to smallest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. One Day on Our Blue Planet… In the Savannah by Ella Bailey. Copyright © 2015 by Ella Bailey. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Flying Eye Books, an imprint of Nobrow Ltd.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a sorting game, and introduce vocabulary (prey, next to).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What is one way a lion cub’s home is similar to your home?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination, focusing on spatial sense.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use position words, such as over, under, above, on, beside, next to, between, in front of, near, and far, top, bottom, up, down, and behind.
Resist impulses (self-regulation); Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Write for different purposes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How is your home like the lion’s home?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Imagine you are an animal who has a home underwater, above ground, and underground.
I see 3 animals. Use location words to tell me where they are.
Can you write a story about an animal living in a land no one has ever seen? What is its home like?
Imagine the perfect animal home. Can you create it?
Make up a name for the perfect animal home and write it down. What sounds do you hear in the name of the animal home?
What ideas do you have for creating a new animal home no one has ever seen? What materials will you use to build it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. One Day on Our Blue Planet… In the Savannah by Ella Bailey. Copyright © 2015 by Ella Bailey. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Flying Eye Books, an imprint of Nobrow Ltd.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one count per item.
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate use of location words (“over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” “far,” etc.).
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate use of location words (“over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” “far,” etc.).
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss people, places, things, and actions.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Demonstrate use of location words (“over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” “far,” etc.).
Regulate own behavior with occasional reminders or assistance from teacher.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
